stem: A 32-year-old G2P1 client has just experienced spontaneous rupture of membranes (SROM). Immediately after, the fetal heart rate (FHR) drops to 70 bpm. Based on the documentation in the Intrapartum Fetal Monitoring & Emergency Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute fetal bradycardia following membrane rupture.
Background: Term pregnancy. Cervix 6cm/80%/-2 station.
Assessment: FHR is 70 bpm with no recovery. Vaginal exam reveals a 'soft, pulsating loop' ahead of the head.
Recommendation: Immediate surgical delivery.

tabs.title: Intrapartum Emergency Log
tabs.content:

actionOptions.text: Keep gloved fingers in the vagina to manually elevate the presenting part off the cord
Position the client in the Knee-Chest or Trendelenburg position
Perform a rapid Leopold maneuver to turn the baby
Instruct the client to push vigorously to deliver the cord first

parameterOptions.text: Maternal oxygenation and status of cord pulsations
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is an Umbilical Cord Prolapse (c2). When the membranes rupture while the fetal head is at a high station (-2), the cord can wash down ahead of the head. As the head descends, it compresses the cord, causing severe bradycardia (70 bpm). Priority #1 is maintaining your hand in the vagina to push the head UP and off the cord (a1). Priority #2 is using gravity (Knee-Chest/Trendelenburg) (a2) to keep the fetus away from the pelvis. Monitoring focuses on the FHR (p1) and cord pulsations (p2).
clinicalPearls: DO NOT remove your hand. If you find a prolapsed cord, you are going to the OR with that patient, and your hand stays there until the surgeon says otherwise.
If the cord is protruding from the vagina, don't try to shove it back in; wrap it in warm, saline-soaked sterile gauze to prevent vasospasm.
Call for help immediately, but keep your hand in place.

questionTrap.trap: Removing the hand to find a wedge or go get the doctor.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: If you remove the hand, the head will crush the cord and the baby will die. Call for help with your VOICE, but keep the hand in place.

mnemonic.title: Cord Care
mnemonic.expansion: C-Call for help. O-Off (Get head off cord). R-Reposition (Knee-Chest). D-Deliver fast (C-section).
